awd_titl_txt: RUI: Structure and Properties of New, Practical Glasses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by two Programs in the Division of Materials Research: Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) and Ceramics (CER).

NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Novel glasses are important for new generations of devices, flat screens, and detectors. Candidate glasses are being prepared and characterized at Coe College in collaboration with many groups around the world (e.g., in Brazil, Canada, Japan, and the United Kingdom). The glass preparations are often non-traditional and use rapid cooling (about 1,000,000 C/s), laser aero-levitation to nearly 3000 C, and alternative chemical approaches. The characterization of these glasses probe the atomic structure and related physical properties. The atomic structure is identified using an array of spectroscopies. Physical properties that are important include the glass softening temperature, the efficient use of space by the atoms, the compositional limits for glass formation, and electrical conductivity.  Projects focus on glasses in medicine, developing conducting glasses for medical and particle detectors, manufacturing glass composites that inhibit bacteria, and glow-in-the-dark crystals that last hours. Broader impacts include the training of about 50 undergraduate and high school students and reaching out to local schools and across campus.  Based on history, it is anticipated that nearly 30 of these students will continue into graduate programs. Students serve the nation in industry and national labs in materials science, computer science, electrical engineering, and several other areas of engineering and physics.  

TECHNICAL DETAILS: In an age of fiber optics and displays, innovative glasses are being studied using roller-quenching, laser aero-levitation, and chemical solution techniques including sol-gel methods. These approaches allow glasses to be made with reluctant formulations including binary and ternary vanadate glasses. These glasses are important as conductive glasses in detectors, high alkali content borate glasses for bactericidal uses, and scintillating alkali and alkaline-earth borosilicate glasses that incorporate inorganic and organic scintillators such as ZnO and P-terphenyl.  Students are trained in several techniques including nuclear magnetic resonance, Raman and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopies, neutron scattering, atomic force microscopy, X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy, and laser induced time-of-flight mass spectroscopy. Also, students employ molecular dynamics simulations of structure using a 120 core computer system. Broader impacts include the extensive research training of ~40 Coe College undergraduate students and additional ten high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of DMR-1746230 were varied and covered several different aspects of research involving undergraduate students working in glass science. Over forty such students participated, under this grant, in fully publishable research at Coe College.  They produced about 30 journal articles and about 100 conference presentations. These undergrads joined 400 from the past and they taught new research students, built and repaired equipment, read research papers, and kept excellent and complete notebooks.

Our students, often working cooperatively on teams, learned several ways to make new kinds of glass. They used nitrogen-filled glove boxes and rapid cooling at the same time. Also, they used laser levitation to form refractory glasses and they used novel chemical routes to glass formation. New glass systems studied include invert (more modifier than glass former) sodium silicates, alkali tellurites, alkali vanadates, lithium hydroxide with lithium chloride or lithium bromide, heavy metal oxide glass, scintillating glasses, novel glass for pattern formation, measurements of hydrophobic glass surfaces, and more. 

They performed many structural studies using Raman spectroscopy, laser desorption time-of-fight mass spectroscopy, at Coe and solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), vibrational spectroscopy (Raman and FTIR) and neutron scattering with colleagues around the world. They also determined physical properties such as density (which led to molar volume and packing efficiency), softening point and crystallization temperatures (known as Tg and Tx), surface wetting on glass, ionic and electrical conductivity, and they extended glass forming ranges.

The paramount broader impact is the training of substantial numbers of undergraduates to do high level publishable research in glass science. Also, these Coe physics students showed elementary and high school students how to form glass and manipulate them by forming, for example, glass fibers. A favorite for outreach is to heat boric acid and form boron oxide glass and steam. Other demos include Rupert's drops and the breaking of commercial tempered glass.

Another broader impact was the organization of a faculty conference on undergraduates doing research in materials and glass science. This was followed up by visits to colleges interested in developing undergraduate research programs in this area.  Schools visited included Hunter College, Seton Hall University, Ursinus College, Swarthmore College, Creighton University, and Tuskegee University. A symposium on undergraduate research, based on this grant, was held at the MS&T conference held in October 2022 in Pittsburgh.  Another two presentations on undergraduate research will take place in Columbus, OH at the 2023 MS&T conference.
